abstract: With Microsoft hoping to buy Yahoo, Google has begun to lay the groundwork to try to delay or derail any deal.
snippet: With Microsoft hoping to buy Yahoo, Google has begun to lay the groundwork to try to delay or derail any deal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It could be payback time.

headline.main: Google and Microsoft Take Up Battle Stations
headline.print_headline: Google and Microsoft Take Up Battle Stations

byline.original: By Stephen Labaton and Miguel Helft

abstract: In a letter outlining Microsoft’s  hopes to Yahoo C.E.O. Jerry Yang, Microsoft C.E.O. Steven Ballmer followed a storied tradition on Wall Street: the bear hug letter.
snippet: In a letter outlining Microsoft’s  hopes to Yahoo C.E.O. Jerry Yang, Microsoft C.E.O. Steven Ballmer followed a storied tradition on Wall Street: the bear hug letter.
lead_paragraph: Steven Ballmer was laying it on thick.

headline.main: The Art of Giving a Bear Hug
headline.print_headline: The Art Of Giving A Bear Hug

abstract: If Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, is expecting a white knight to help him keep the company from being frog-marched down the aisle with Microsoft, he shouldn’t put his hopes on the private equity quarter, according to industry observers.
lead_paragraph: If Yahoo‘s chief executive, Jerry Yang, is expecting a white knight to help him keep the company from being frog-marched down the aisle with Microsoft, he shouldn’t put his hopes on the private equity quarter, according to industry observers.

headline.main: Fading Prospects for a White Knight for Yahoo

abstract: Microsoft said on Monday it might borrow money for the first time in its history to fund a portion of its $44.6 billion unsolicited offer for Yahoo.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Monday it might borrow money for the first time in its history to fund a portion of its $44.6 billion unsolicited offer for Yahoo.

headline.main: Microsoft Eyes Debt Sale to Finance Yahoo Bid

abstract: In sending a public letter to his intended takeover target, Microsoft‘s Steven Ballmer became the latest acquisition-hungry chief to try the time-honored “bear hug.” In this case, there were definitely claws behind his warm and fuzzy words to Yahoo, as DealBook explains in its latest column in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: In sending a public letter to his intended takeover target, Microsoft‘s Steven Ballmer became the latest acquisition-hungry chief to try the time-honored “bear hug.” In this case, there were definitely claws behind his warm and fuzzy words to Yahoo, as DealBook explains in its latest column in The New York Times.

headline.main: Microsoft and the Art of the Bear Hug

abstract: With Yahoo reluctant, Microsoft aggressive and Google determined, the struggle for one of the Internet’s pioneers has quickly become a full-on brawl. But with so many (theoretical) outcomes, how will the battle over Microsoft’s $31-per-share takeover offer play out?
lead_paragraph: With Yahoo reluctant, Microsoft aggressive and Google determined, the struggle for one of the Internet’s pioneers has quickly become a full-on brawl. But with so many (theoretical) outcomes, how will the battle over Microsoft’s $31-per-share takeover offer play out?

headline.main: Setting the Odds on Yahoo’s Fate
